solver.variables

Interface SetVar

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Comparable<Variable>, Identity, Serializable, Variable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    FixedSetVarImpl, SetVarImpl

    public interface SetVar
extends Variable
    A Set Variable is defined by a domain which is a set interval [kernel,envelope] The kernel is the set of elements that must belong to every single solution. The envelope is the set of elements that may belong to at least one solution.

    One must notice that in this context, a VALUE of the variable is a set of integers.

    Since:
    15 nov. 2012
    Author:
    Charles Prud'homme, Jean-Guillaume Fages

    • Field Detail

      • END

        static final int END
        Constant used for enumerating elements in the envelope or the kernel of a SetVar. This value indicates that the iteration is over: for(int e=getKernelFirst(); e!=SetVar.END; e=getKernelNext()){ // something }
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getKernelFirst

        int getKernelFirst()
        Get the first element currently in the kernel domain of this. Returns END if the set is empty. Note that elements are not sorted. To iterate over elements that are present in the kernel, do the following loop: for(int e=getKernelFirst(); e!=SetVar.END; e=getKernelNext()){ // something }
        Returns:
        the first element in the kernel or END if it is empty.

      • getKernelNext

        int getKernelNext()
        Get the next element in the kernel domain of this. Returns END once all elements have been visited. To iterate over elements that are present in the kernel, do the following loop: for(int e=getKernelFirst(); e!=SetVar.END; e=getKernelNext()){ // something }
        Returns:
        the next element in the kernel, if any, or END otherwise.

      • getKernelSize

        int getKernelSize()
        Get the number of elements in the kernel domain of this.
        Returns:
        the number of elements currently present in the kernel.

      • kernelContains

        boolean kernelContains(int element)
        Test whether element is present or not in the kernel
        Parameters:
        element -
        Returns:
        true iff element is present in the kernel

      • getEnvelopeFirst

        int getEnvelopeFirst()
        Get the first element currently in the envelope domain of this. Returns END if the set is empty. Note that elements are not sorted. To iterate over elements that are present in the envelope, do the following loop: for(int e=getEnvelopeFirst(); e!=SetVar.END; e=getEnvelopeNext()){ // something }
        Returns:
        the first element in the envelope or END if it is empty.

      • getEnvelopeNext

        int getEnvelopeNext()
        Get the next element in the envelope domain of this. Returns END once all elements have been visited. To iterate over elements that are present in the envelope, do the following loop: for(int e=getEnvelopeFirst(); e!=SetVar.END; e=getEnvelopeNext()){ // something }
        Returns:
        the next element in the envelope, if any, or END otherwise.

      • getEnvelopeSize

        int getEnvelopeSize()
        Get the number of elements in the envelope domain of this.
        Returns:
        the number of elements currently present in the envelope.

      • envelopeContains

        boolean envelopeContains(int element)
        Test whether element is present or not in the envelope
        Parameters:
        element -
        Returns:
        true iff element is present in the envelope

        cause -

                           throws ContradictionException

      • instantiateTo

        boolean instantiateTo(int[] value,
                    ICause cause)
                      throws ContradictionException
        Enforces the set variable to contain exactly the set of integers given in parameter
        Parameters:
        value - a set of integers
        cause -
        Returns:
        true iff a domain modification occurred
        Throws:
        ContradictionException

      • getValues

        int[] getValues()
        Retrieves the current value of the variable if instantiated, otherwise the lower bound (kernel).
        Returns:
        the current value (or kernel if not yet instantiated).
